page.title: 18Village Carnivals
page.content: Carnivals are an important part of Cornish summers. Throughout the summer months, people in towns & villages stage their own carnival activities. Fancy dress processions mark the end of each carnival week. After the costumes have been judged, the people join the parade, either on foot or on a decorated float. In Cornwall there are Fairy Queens and Carnival Queens. The Fairy Queens are young girls of about five or six. They wear short, frilly, sequined dresses with velvet capes around their shoulders. Usually they ride in the procession in a decorated hatchback car. The Carnival Queens are older girls and they have two attendants each. Their dresses are long and each group have their own choice of colours. The Queens go to many other carnivals hoping to win cups.
